text: Onboard AIColours Task Extract the colour palette of a website, grouping colours based on semantic purpose Anatomy of a Colour Palette Monochromatic Analogous Complementary Split-Complementary Polygonal In general, a colour palette can be classified into one of five classes The Model ● The model will be a bi-directional transformer ○ Can see the entire colour palette at once ○ Can handle arbitrary lengths of palette ○ Without position embeddings there is no inductive bias towards relative order ● The model performs two tasks 1. Classifying the palette as one of the previously mentioned classes 2. Clustering the colours based on their overall purpose within the palette Training with Synthetic Data ● Training on artificially generated data can be convenient ○ No issues with dataset size ○ Can control quality ● However, any discrepancy between the synthetic distribution and real world data can decrease your model’s generalization ○ This typically comes in the form of overfitting Pretraining on Real World Data ● Training from synthetic data can often lead to collapse in a local minimum ● To resolve this, the model was first trained using Sim-CLR on colour palettes sourced from existing VeryConnect customers + the open source WikiArt dataset * These loss curves are from quite early in the data generation / hyper parameter tuning process Random Transforms and LAB When generating a colour palette for training, first an “idealised” colour palette is generated belonging to a random class. Next, random transforms are performed. Importantly, these transforms shouldn’t change the palette’s class. Humans perceive colour in a non-uniform way which standard colour spaces (e.g. RGB) don’t account for. LAB does. “Idealised” split-complementary palette After LAB space transforms Results Prediction: Monochromatic Synthetic Data Using clusters to analyse a https://www.cmhp.org.uk/ Logos Task Extract the company logo from a website Approach One: OCR + Fuzzy String Similarity cinfo Biel Bern New location, proven services Approach One: OCR + Fuzzy String Similarity cinfo Biel Bern New location, proven services Match to Keys cinfo Careers in International Cooperation | International development, humanitarian aid, peacebuilding | cinfo … User-provided/auto-generated keys Return Image with Highest Match 80+% accuracy on VeryConnect Customers Approach Two: A Bespoke Model Using a set of 1,391 companies, we set up a site to manually label logo images sourced from their homepages along with a set of google search results Data Gathering The Part of AI Everyone Tries to Avoid The Model 1. A vision model (potentially pre-trained on a publicly available logo dataset produces a latent vector for each image 2. A transformer processes these vectors (with additional metadata), selecting the logos from them Results ● Due to the time-consuming nature of the data gathering process, along with challenges and time pressures from other parts of the project, we were only able to gather around 100 training examples ● Top-1 accuracy on an unseen portion of the dataset: 64% ● This number may be higher with a larger dataset, but the trade off in time dedication may not be worth it
